journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Evaluation of weather influence on mechanical and viscoelastic properties of polyetherimide/carbon fiber composites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry – ITA, Praça Mal. Eduardo Gomes, São José dos Campos, S.P., Brazil
2Department of Materials and Technology - UNESP, Av. Ariberto Pereira da Cunha, Guaratinguetá, S.P., Brazil

author-notes.corresp: Natassia L Batista, Department of Chemistry – ITA, Praça Mal. Eduardo Gomes, 50, Vila das Acácias, CEP:12228-901, São José dos Campos, S.P., Brazil. Email: natassia_lb@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In order to investigate how environmental degradation affects the mechanical and thermal performance of polyetherimide/carbon fiber laminates, in this work different weathering were conducted. Additionally, dynamic mechanical analysis, interlaminar shear strength tests and non-destructive inspections were performed on this composite before and after being submitted to hygrothermal, UV radiation and thermal shock weathering. According to our results, hygrothermally aged samples had their glass transition temperature and elastic and storage moduli reduced by plasticization effect. Photooxidation, due to UV radiation exposure, occurred only on the surface of the laminates. Thermal shock induced a reversible stress on the composite’s interface region. The results revealed that the mechanical behavior can vary during weather exposure but since this variation is only subtle, this thermoplastic laminate can be considered for high-performance applications, such as aerospace.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, several thermoplastic composite materials are being considered for use in different fields, ranging from sporting goods to aerospace parts. In the aeronautical field, high-performance thermoplastic composites are increasing among the thermosetting composites and have been applied in several parts, such as wings, landing gear doors, floor panels, radomes and flaps, where the long-term properties are of primary importance.1,2 Compared with the other polymers commonly used in the structural application, polyetherimide (PEI) is a high-performance amorphous engineering thermoplastic, presenting remarkable mechanical properties even at elevated temperature due to its high glass transition temperature (Tg ∼ 216–220℃), as well as an outstanding fracture resistance into different testing conditions.3

The effects of environmental exposure of polymer composites and the long-term retention of properties, on the other hand, are significant concerns for outdoor applications.4 In service, the composites are exposed to a variety of conditions such as moisture, ultraviolet (UV) radiation and temperature variation, which can affect their mechanical properties.5,6 The development of a comprehension of the environmental deterioration is of outmost importance to extend the service life of materials.2

Absorbed moisture has many detrimental effects on material performance since this process can cause swelling and degradation on polymer composites. In addition, higher temperatures accelerate diffusion rates of moisture and generally accelerate aging in a complex manner.4 Several studies have shown the effects of absorbed water and aging temperature on the physical and mechanical properties of composite materials.7–12 Results were found to obey a Fickian diffusion model.1 The diffusion is a thermally activated process and its temperature dependence can be expressed by the Arrhenius equation:13 D=D0exp(-EaRT) in which Ea is the activation energy of diffusion, D0 is the pre-exponential factor and R is the gas constant. Typical activation energies of moisture diffusion in polymeric composites range from 20 to 80 kJ/mol.13

In polymeric composites, matrix is the most exposed constituent to moisture, but it also attacks the fiber/matrix interface.2,14 Water absorption may lead to physical and chemical changes, which affect the viscoelastic behavior of the material.14,15

Physical degradation consists of plasticization and swelling of the matrix.16 The diffusion of water molecules into the polymer structure forces the macromolecules apart, so that the material expands or swells with the increase of its free volume.17 This increase in chain separation results in a reduction of the secondary intermolecular bonding forces and an increase of the molecular chains and side groups mobility, causing a reversible plasticization. As a consequence, the Tg of the polymer is lowered and the material becomes softer and more ductile.5,17

Chemical degradation includes matrix hydrolysis, interface hydrolysis and fiber degradation, under specific conditions.7,16 The water diffusion may lead to chain dissociation or chain segmentation, which is referred as hydrolysis. A permanent weight loss may also occur due to leaching of low-molecular weight molecules, which can cause an irreversible stiffening of these materials.5,8 In some cases, hydrolysis may cause material damages, such as microcracking.5

UV radiation also can generate degradation on polymeric composites. Photo-degradation may involve various changes, such as oxidation, chain scission and crosslinking.6,9 Chain scission can result in more chain mobility, while crosslinking restricts molecular mobility and reduces the ability of the material to accommodate externally applied deformation.10,11 Moreover, density gradients due to oxidation gradients on the polymer matrix cause stresses, which combined with chain scission, could initiate and propagate cracks. Cracks on the surface result in light diffusion (a whitening effect in appearance) and also lead to the mechanical properties loss.9,12 In addition to the described effects, previous studies reported that the presence of water during exposure to UV radiation accelerates degradation of the matrix and matrix/reinforcement interface.9,10,18 Nakamura et al.18 observed that these two environments cause severe microcracking and erosion on composite matrix.

Large cyclic temperature variations during an airplane flight may also reduce polymeric composite’s life.19 Under thermal loading, stresses may develop as a result of the difference in the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) between the fibers and the matrix, and consequently, of adjacent plies stacked with different orientations in the laminate.19,20 These stresses, in some cases, can be large enough to initiate material damage such as matrix microcracking. Usually, these microcracks form at the interface between the constituents and can reduce the strength of the material, as well as act as sites for environmental degradation and nucleation of macrocracks.20 Moreover, microcracks can act as nuclei for further damage types, such as delamination and longitudinal splitting.19

The purpose of the present work is to investigate the effect of moisture absorption, UV radiation and thermal shock aging on the mechanical and viscoelastic properties of PEI/carbon fiber composites. In order to expose the laminates to these environments, three different climatic chambers were used: hygrothermal, UV radiation combined with water condensation and thermal shock. The weathering changes in mechanical and viscoelastic behaviors were evaluated by dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA), interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) test and by determination of tensile and shear modulus from resonant frequencies. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was also conducted in order to characterize the structure modification caused by UV radiation aging.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PEI/carbon fiber laminate used in this study consisted of eight plies of carbon fiber fabric reinforcements (0°/ + 45°/ − 45°/90°)s with 5 Harness Satin (5HS) textile style. This laminate, with 50% of carbon fiber in volume, was supplied by Ten Cate Advanced Composite Materials Company, located in the Netherlands.

sec.title: Hygrothermal weathering
sec.p: Accelerated water absorption was performed on a controlled Marconi climatic chamber, model MA835/UR. Before weathering, the samples were dried in an oven at 60℃ for 24 h. The specimens were exposed to 80℃ and 90% relative humidity atmosphere in a chamber during a period of eight weeks. Every week the specimens were removed from the chamber and weighed in a high precision balance in order to evaluate the amount of water taken up. The hygrothermal exposure was based on ASTM D 5229/D 5229 M 04 standard.21

sec.title: UV radiation weathering
sec.p: Artificial photodegradation was carried out using an accelerated weathering tester (Model QUV/spray with solar eye irradiance control, QUV/Se; Q-Panel Lab Products, Cleveland, OH) following the ASTM G 154 standard.22 The damages caused by sunlight, rain and dew were reproduced by 8 h periodic cycles at 60℃ under UV-A at light and 4 h at 50℃ under water condensation provided by the vapor generator from the water bath. The UV-A radiation is provided by fluorescent UV lamps with 0.35 W/m2 irradiance and 340 nm wavelength. The light intensity emitted is monitored constantly by the “Solar-Eye” radiation detectors and calibrated every 400 h of service to evaluate the lamps’ performance. The samples were submitted to the aging process for durations of 600, 1200 and 2400 h.

In order to determine the possible chemical changes promoted during UV weathering the specimens were monitored by FT-IR experiments. The infrared spectrum was acquired using Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrophotometer, at a resolution of 4 cm–1. The spectra were taken in reflection mode in the region of 550–4000 cm−1.

sec.title: Thermal shock weathering
sec.p: Thermal cycling weathering was performed on an Envirotronics two zone vertical thermal shock test chamber (Model TSV 5-2-2-2-AC). This equipment has an upper compartment, responsible for heating, and a lower compartment, responsible for cooling the specimens. The communication between these two compartments is made by a vertical lift, which allows adjusting the time of permanence in each compartment. To investigate the thermal shock behavior on PEI/carbon fiber composite, this laminate was exposed to several cycles, each one of 10 min at −50℃ followed by 10 min at +80℃, in order to simulate a flight envelop of an airplane. The thermal cycling was carried out for 1000 and 2000 cycles.

sec.title: Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA)
sec.p: Dynamic mechanical analyses (DMA) were performed in order to evaluate the influence of the conditionings on viscoelastic properties and Tg of PEI/carbon fiber specimens. These analyses were carried out using a dual cantilever bending mode with 50 mm × 10 mm × 2.5 mm of dimension. A frequency of 1 Hz and a maximum displacement of 10 µm were used over a temperature range of 30 to 250℃ at a heating rate of 3℃/min. The dynamic measurements were carried out in a Dynamic Mechanical Analyzer from Seiko SII Exstar 6000.

sec.title: ILSS
sec.p: ILSS tests were conducted to evaluate the weathering effects on PEI/carbon fiber laminate interface, according to ASTM D2344 standard,23 using five specimens with dimensions of 15 mm × 6 mm × 2.5 mm. These tests were performed on a Shimadzu Precision Universal Tester (Autograph AG-X Series), at a constant cross-speed of 1.3 mm/min.

sec.title: Determination of Young’s and shear modulus
sec.p: The impulse excitation of vibration was used to determine Young’s and shear moduli from the natural frequency using a rectangular specimen under flexure and torsion modes, respectively. At the technique applied, the specimen is lightly stroked with an electromagnetic impulse, the acoustic response is captured with an acoustic sensor and processed by software, which calculates the Young’s and shear moduli from the natural frequencies of vibration.

Calculation of the Young’s and shear modulus from the natural frequencies depends only on the dimensions and weight of specimen. The Young’s modulus can be calculated from the material’s natural frequency in flexure mode by using the following relationship: E=0.9465(mff2b)(L3t3)T where m is the weight of the specimen, ff is the natural frequency of the bar under flexural loading, and b, L, and t are the width, length, and thickness of the bar, respectively. T parameter can be obtained from: T=1+6.858(tL)2

While the shear modulus can be calculated from the material’s natural frequency in torsion mode by using the following equation: G=4Lmft2bt(B1+A) where ft is the natural frequency of the bar under torsion mode. A and B parameters can be calculated by: B=(b/t+t/b4(t/b)-2.52(t/b)2+0.21(t/b)6)A=(0.5062-0.8776(b/t)+0.3504(b/t)2-0.0078(b/t)312.03(b/t)+9.892(b/t)2).

The impulse excitation technique was applied using a Sonelastic® equipment, developed by ATCP – Physical Engineering, at Brazil. This non-destructive test was performed according to ASTM 1876 standard, using specimens with dimension of 100 mm × 20 mm × 2.5 mm at the warp direction.

sec.title: Hygrothermal weathering
sec.p:
The moisture absorption behavior of PEI/carbon fiber laminate specimens exposed to 80℃ and 90% RH is shown in Figure 1, where the percent weight gain is plotted as a function of the square root of the exposure time. As can be observed, the studied material exhibited a saturation curve after 50 days (∼35(hours)1/2) with a 0.25% maximum increase in weight. The experimental values showed deviation from the Fickian fitting curve with a slight drop in weight. At this point, the desorption process overcomes sorption. Figure 1.
Experimental data of water absorption against square root of time for PEI/carbon fiber composites during hygrothermal conditioning.

During moisture exposure, surface absorption by diffusion through the matrix is the primary mechanism of water uptake, in which water molecules are transported from high moisture concentration to lower moisture concentration areas. Moisture can also be transported to the bulk of the composite specimens by the capillary action through microcracks at the fiber/matrix interface. Water molecules sorption leads to the increase in sample weight. However, water can also promote leaching of low-molecular weight groups from the polymer through desorption, causing a weight decrease.5

The effects of humidity on the viscoelastic response of PEI/carbon fiber composite are presented in Figure 2(a–c). In this study, the temperature at the onset of the storage modulus (E′) curve (Figure 1a) was chosen for being the most conservative form to determine Tg. For the not weathered specimen, Tg occurred at 174℃ and decreased at 6℃ after hygrothermal weathering, as expected. The phenomenon of Tg decrease for polymeric composites exposed to humidity is related to plasticization, caused by weakening or even destruction of secondary links between polymeric chains, which induces an increase in the chain mobility. As a consequence of this phenomenon, the storage modulus decreased in 11.67%, as can be observed in Figure 2(a). Figure 2.
DMA results after hygrothermal weathering: (a) storage modulus; (b) loss modulus; and (c) tan δ.

The loss modulus (E″) is related to the energy dissipation mechanisms in materials. Composite materials with poor interfacial bonding tend to dissipate more energy. Since Figure 2(b) shows a decrease on E″ values after hygrothermal weathering it can be inferred that the humidity did not attack or reduce fiber/matrix interface adhesion.

The ratio of loss modulus to storage modulus is defined as tan δ and it is an indicative parameter of the mechanical damping ability of the material tested. The damping properties of the material provide the balance between the elastic and viscous phases in a polymeric structure. However, as depicted in Figure 2(c), no remarkable changes in the tan δ values were observed in this work, which indicates that the damping ability was not significantly affected.

In Table 1, ILSS values of PEI/carbon fiber composites are shown for hygrothermal weathered and not weathered specimens. A slight increase of 6% is seen at the end of the weathering. This result is also fitted to the above DMA results, in which the material stiffness decreased and the fiber/matrix interface was not reduced. Composites shear properties are mainly dominated by matrix and fiber/matrix interface. Due to the plasticizing effect of water there was probably a stress relief of the laminate due to a better accommodation of the polymer macromolecules, while the fiber/matrix was not reduced, inducing an increase in the ILSS value. Table 1.
ILSS results after hygrothermal weathering.
Not weathered Hygrothermal weathering
ILSS (MPa) 93.81 ± 4.50 99.65 ± 3.71

Table 2 presents the dynamic Young’s and shear moduli (E and G, respectively) of PEI/carbon fiber composites before and after being submitted to hygrothermal weathering. For both cases there was a decrease of the moduli value, of 2.7% for the Young’s modulus and of 20.9% for the shear modulus. However, the shear modulus is more affected by alterations in the polymeric matrix generating a higher reduction on its value; since the Young’s modulus is more affected by the reinforcement the reduction observed was less severe. As it has already been mentioned, the presence of water molecules into the PEI structure forces the macromolecules apart causing plasticization. Owing to plasticization, the material stiffness was reduced and, consequently, the Young’s and shear moduli were reduced as well. These results are also in agreement with the previously observed in DMA. Table 2.
Hygrothermal weathering effect on Young’s and shear moduli.
Not weathered Hygrothermal weathering
E (GPa) 44.98 ± 0.14 43.77 ± 0.17
G (GPa) 13.27 ± 0.04 10.50 ± 0.17

sec.title: UV radiation weathering
sec.p:
The weight loss during UV weathering of PEI/carbon fiber laminates is shown in Figure 3, where the percent weight loss is plotted as a function of the exposure time. The behavior presented in the curve is a result of two main concomitant processes: photo-degradation and plasticization. During weathering, the samples were exposed to alternating cycles of UV irradiation and water spraying. Based on previous studies on environmental degradation of composites,18 UV radiation exposure and moisture condensation can generate several modes of damage. UV radiation leads to embrittlement and microcracking owing to photochemical reactions in the polymeric matrix. While moisture absorption, as previously described, leads to volumetric expansion, plasticization and hydrolysis. Thus, microcracking that occurs due to photo-degradation facilitates moisture entry while moisture condensation washes away the water-soluble products of UV-initiated photochemical reactions.18,24 Moreover, when the microcracking occurs in combination with water spraying, the degradation appears to be accelerated by erosion of the surface.24 Figure 3.
Experimental data of weight loss against time for PEI/carbon fiber composites during UV conditioning.

As it can be observed, the weight loss curve can be divided into three parts, according to the main actuating mechanism in each period of time. The first part, from 0 to 600 h of exposure, indicates the occurrence of photo-degradation that leads to a decrease in sample weight through microcracking; the second, from 600 to 1200 h, microcrackings permit an increase in moisture ingress, diminishing the weight loss and even weight gain, at approximately 800 h of weathering; the third, from 1200 to 2400 h, shows a return to a more intense weight loss, dominated mainly by photo-degradation and possible leaching of water-soluble products of UV-initiated photochemical reactions.

FT-IR analyses were carried out in order to identify possible chemical modifications after the UV radiation weathering. Figure 4 presents the peaks of the not weathered specimens. This spectra shows the main bands for the imide ring, at 1778 and 1718 cm−1, corresponding to asymmetric and symmetric C=O stretching, and at 1352 cm−1, attributed to C–N stretching, respectively.25–27 Vibrations at 1267, 1234, 1074 and 1014 cm−1 are due to C–O–C stretching of aromatic ether.25 Although these bands are sufficient to confirm that PEI is the analyzed polymer, the presence of characteristic groups of aromatic rings is also indispensable. Bands at 3062, 2965 and 2917 cm−1 are attributed to C–H stretching, bands at 1599, 1495 and 1476 cm−1 correspond to C=C stretching, and bands at 846 and 742 cm−1 are due to substituted aromatic rings. Figure 4.
FT-IR spectra of PEI/carbon fiber before weathering superposed to 2400 h of UV radiation weathering.

Some changes were observed after 2400 h of UV radiation weathering, as shown in Figure 4. The increasing band around 3650–3000 cm−1 suggests the presence of O–H due to humidity absorption during condensation periods. The intensification at the peak at 1234 cm−1 is probably a result of a not pronounced oxidation process, forming C–O bonds. However, the fact that PEI possesses C–O and C=O bonds in its macromolecule makes the identification of oxidation formation more difficult.

The amount of moisture in the specimens drifts in the course of UV radiation weathering, as observed at O–H band around 3650–3000 cm−1 (Figure 5). The higher content of water was found after 1200 h of weathering, reaffirming the speculations that in this period the weight gain was due to higher moisture absorption, compared to weight loss. Figure 5.
FT-IR spectra of PEI/carbon fiber during UV radiation weathering.

The effects of UV weathering on the viscoelastic behavior of PEI/carbon fiber laminates are presented in Figure 6(a–c). The Tg, taken from the onset of the storage modulus curve (Figure 6a), did not have a significant change in the course of weathering. However, the samples exposed to 2400 h of UV weathering had a storage modulus 5% smaller than the unexposed sample. As mentioned before, UV radiation induces photochemical reactions that lead to microcracking and embrittlement of the composite matrix. In addition, moisture condensation within UV radiation is a synergistic combination that accelerates surface erosion. The degradation process produced significantly adverse effects on the storage modulus only after 2400 h, caused by the embrittlement of the polymer matrix. Figure 6.
DMA results after UV weathering: (a) storage modulus; (b) loss modulus; and (c) tan δ.

As seen in Figure 6(b), the loss modulus values increased nearly 25% with UV weathering. Materials with higher E″ tend to dissipate more energy. Therefore, photo-oxidation was probably severe enough to induce greater mobility and greater energy dissipation. The plasticization effect intensified the increase on polymer mobility. Consequently, the samples weathered during 1200 h, where plasticization was the predominating degradation mechanism, presented higher E″ values (27.4%).

Tan δ also increased with UV weathering, as shown in Figure 6(c). Since tan δ values can be comprehended as E″/E′, the damping ability increased mainly due to E″ increase caused by photo-degradation and plasticization. Nevertheless, the E′ decrease of the 2400 h samples contributed to modify tan δ value, as an indication that photo-degradation is the main actuating mechanism at the final period of weathering.

The ILSS values of not weathered and UV weathered samples after periods of 600, 1200 and 2400 h are shown in Table 3. As can be observed, the ILSS values showed a small decrease after 600 and 2400 h of exposure. The small variation indicates that matrix erosion, under exposure to alternating UV radiation and water spraying, occurred only on the surface and were probably not very deep. Therefore, these losses in the PEI matrix were too small to affect significantly the overall mechanical characteristics of the composites. Nevertheless, the specimens exposed to 1200 h of UV weathering presented higher ILSS values, similar to hygrothermally weathered specimens, once water ingress was more severe. Table 3.
ILSS results after UV weathering.
Not weathered 600 h 1200 h 2400 h
ILSS (MPa) 93.81 ± 4.50 91.64 ± 6.07 102.67 ± 7.11 91.05 ± 6.62

Table 4 presents the dynamic Young’s and shear moduli of PEI/carbon fiber composites before and after UV radiation weathering. It was observed that the behavior of the analyzed material was similar for both moduli, Young’s and shear. As it can be seen, after 600 h of weathering, there were decreases in E and G values (1.07 and 7.78%, respectively), that became even more significant after 1200 h (1.98 and 11.15%, respectively). However, the specimens weathered during 2400 h presented their Young’s and shear moduli recovered. It reveals that photo-degradation was probably not very severe, once the specimens exposed to longer periods of weathering showed closer moduli values to not weathered specimens. Moreover, the reduction of water content from 1200 to 2400 h of weathering could also have led to leaching of low-molecular weight molecules, which can cause stiffening of the material. Table 4.
UV radiation weathering effect on Young’s and shear moduli.
Not weathered 600 h 1200 h 2400 h
E (GPa) 44.98 ± 0.14 44.50 ± 0.13 44.09 ± 0.12 45.02 ± 0.22
G (GPa) 13.27 ± 0.04 12.24 ± 0.11 11.79 ± 0.21 13.36 ± 0.32

sec.title: Thermal shock weathering
sec.p:
The effects of thermal shock on the viscoelastic response of PEI/carbon fiber composite are presented in Figure 7(a–c). The Tg, obtained by using the onset of the storage modulus curve (Figure 7a), did not show a significant change in the course of weathering. On the other hand, the storage modulus presented a small decrease (around 5%) when specimens were analyzed after to be exposed to 1000 cycles. However, no decrease has been found on the storage modulus in specimens exposed up to 2000 cycles, indicating that the decrease was probably not due to microcracking formation. Figure 7.
DMA results after thermal shock weathering: (a) storage modulus; (b) loss modulus; and (c) tan δ.

The results obtained from loss modulus curve (Figure 7b) indicate that there is no significant increase after the thermal shock weathering. Therefore, the cyclic thermal shocks probably did not induce microcracking formation on fiber/matrix interface.

Tan δ values also did not change significantly, as it can be seen in Figure 7(c). Thus, overall, the DMA results indicate that no damage on composites matrix or interface was verified after the cyclic thermal shocks.

ILSS values of PEI/carbon fiber laminates weathered by thermal cycles and not weathered are shown in Table 5. According to the found results, no significant variations of the ILSS results can be observed after the thermal cycling weathering, in agreement with the found DMA results. Although ILSS values of the specimens cycled 1000 times show a small decrease, the specimens cycled 2000 times present a small increase of ILSS values, suggesting that thermal cycling was not severe to form microcracks and induce degradation at fiber/matrix interface. Table 5.
ILSS results after thermal shock weathering.
Not weathered 1000 cycles 2000 cycles
ILSS (MPa) 93.81 ± 4.50 90.62 ± 6.85 97.58 ± 2.12

Table 6 presents the dynamic Young’s and shear moduli of PEI/carbon fiber composites before and after UV radiation weathering. As it can be observed, after 1000 thermal cycles there was a small decrease on Young’s and shear moduli (1.92% and 1.07%, respectively). Nevertheless, after 2000 thermal cycles the shear modulus decreased substantially (16.45%), while Young’s modulus was recovered. Table 6.
Thermal shock weathering effect on Young’s and shear moduli.
Not weathered 1000 cycles 2000 cycles
E (GPa) 44.98 ± 0.14 44.12 ± 0.10 44.93 ± 0.17
G (GPa) 13.07 ± 0.04 12.93 ± 0.05 10.92 ± 0.19

Similar recoveries, as found for Young’s modulus, have been related on previous works.28–32 Comparing the results obtained from the impulse excitation technique with DMA and ILSS results, it can be observed that all of them presented a decrease of strength values after 1000 thermal cycles followed by a recovery, when exposed during 2000 thermal cycles. However, at all the tests the specimens were evaluated in the longitudinal and not at transversal direction, as it was done in the torsion mode to obtain shear modulus. Therefore, DMA and ILSS results are according to Young’s modulus results.

A work on the strength variation in composites32 verified a relationship between modulus and reinforcement orientation. The strength improvement on a laminate with fibers oriented at 0° had the Young’s modulus increased, while a strength improvement on a laminate oriented at 45° had the shear modulus increased. A similar behavior was found for the thermal cycled specimens; however, in this case the variation is not related with the reinforcement direction, but with the direction of a reversible stress formation.

The properties recovery observed after 2000 thermal cycles for DMA, ILSS and Young’s modulus, thus as the inversion verified in shear modulus values, indicate that microcracking formation is not likely. Moreover, a previous study, with metallic composites,33 related the results alternation with a reversible stress accommodation on the interfacial region, controlled by a friction mechanism. Although the mechanisms involved in metallic materials are very different from those associated with polymeric composites, the orientation variation of the most affected region by thermal cycling, longitudinal or transversal loadings, indicate a reversible stress formation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Weathering studies were conducted on PEI/carbon fiber laminates. The main conclusions drawn from this study are summarized as follows:
The moisture saturation point for hygrothermally weathered laminates reached nearly 0.25% weight increase. Non-Fickian kinetics was observed to govern the moisture absorption in the final stages of weathering due to possible leaching of low-molecular weight molecules. Matrix plasticization was induced by moisture absorption without degrading the fiber/matrix adhesion.
UV radiation weathering for 2400 h decreased samples weight and storage modulus. However, the bulk was barely affected. Photo-degradation and plasticization were the main actuating mechanisms during UV radiation weathering. The synergistic mechanism obtained by the exposition to UV radiation combined with condensation leads to matrix surface erosion and embrittlement.
Thermal cycling induced reversible stress at fiber/matrix interface, which varied the affected region, longitudinal or transversal. In the studied case, after 1000 thermal cycles the mechanical strength decreased on the longitudinal direction and after 2000 thermal cycles there was a reduction on the transversal direction.
Although the major changes observed in this work seem to be reversible, the variation on strength values reached nearly 20%, deserving attention during the aircraft components use. However, with the results presented in this work it can be concluded that PEI/carbon fiber composites can be applied on the external components of aircrafts.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Financial support for this study was received from CNPq and FAPESP.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Ten Cate for supplying the material. Acknowledgements also go to the 19th International Conference on Composite Materials (ICCM19).
